decline.translation[0].definitions[0].de: a decrease in the quality, quantity, or importance of something
decline.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: the economic decline faced by many cities
The island’s population initially numbered 180, but there was a gradual decline until only 40 people were left.
The port fell into decline in the 1950s.
There has been a decline in the size of families.
the widely held belief that educational standards are in decline
decline.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: sharp/steep
The higher prices caused a sharp decline in sales.
We noticed a rapid decline in his health.
dramatic
The last three years have seen a dramatic decline in the number of tigers in the area.
marked
Hunting led to a marked decline in bird numbers.
gradual
After 1870, there was a gradual decline of the disease.
steady/progressive
There has been a steady decline in club membership.
a long-term decline
The long-term decline in the manufacturing industry is still continuing.
economic/industrial etc decline
This area has been severely affected by long-term industrial decline.
cause/lead to a decline
The use of agricultural chemicals has led to a decline in water quality.
go/fall into decline
At the beginning of the century the cloth trade was going into decline.
suffer a decline
The firm suffered a sharp decline in its profits.
stop/halt a decline
These measures are intended to halt the decline in fish populations.
reverse a decline
The main aim is to reverse the decline of the world’s environment.
see a decline
The 20th century saw a steady decline in the rural population.
decline.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to decrease in quantity or importance
decline.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Spending on information technology has declined.
Car sales have declined by a quarter.
After the war, the city declined in importance.
decline.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to say no politely when someone invites you somewhere, offers you something, or wants you to do something
decline.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: Offered the position of chairman, Smith declined, preferring to keep his current job.
Mary declined a hot drink and went to her room.
Mary declined Jay’s invitation to dinner.
The court declined to review her case.
The minister declined to comment (=refused to speak to people who report the news) about the progress of the peace talks.
decline.translation[1].definitions[2].de: to become gradually worse in quality
decline.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: Her health has been declining progressively for several months.
Qualified staff are leaving and standards are declining.
decline.translation[1].definitions[3].de: if a noun, pronoun, or adjective declines, its form changes according to whether it is the subject, object etc of a sentence
decline.translation[1].definitions[4].de: if you decline a noun, pronoun, or adjective, you show the various forms that it can take
decline.translation[2].definitions[0].de: if an industry or country declines, it becomes less profitable, productive, wealthy etc
decline.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: This type of business is a declining sector of the UK.
decline.translation[2].definitions[1].de: if sales, profits, production etc decline, they become less
decline.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: Car sales have declined by a quarter.
As profitability declines, people have started to leave farming.
decline.translation[3].definitions[0].de: when sales, profits, production etc become less
decline.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: Exports had collapsed, causing a sharp decline in national income.
The increase in profit came despite a decline in sales.
decline.translation[3].definitions[1].de: when an industry or country becomes less profitable, productive, wealthy etc
decline.translation[3].definitions[1].ex: The decline in the province’s manufacturing sector is worrying.
a false and damaging picture of a nation in decline
